questions.q: The following are signs of life in live births except
questions.explanation: Heartbeat, breathing, voluntary muscle movements, pulsation of the umbilical cord are all signs of life in live births

questions.q: Stillborn is described as
questions.A: Fetus that shows at least one sign of life
questions.B: Fetus without any sign of life and weighs <1000g
questions.C: Fetus without any sign of life and weighs ≥1000g
questions.explanation: A fetus without any sign of life and weight ≥1000g is considered stillborn, while a fetus without any sign of life weighing <1000g is termed an abortus.

questions.q: APGAR score. Which is correct
questions.A: Scores at 5, 10, 15, and 20 minutes may signal the need for resuscitation
questions.B: 1-minute APGAR indicates probability of successful resuscitation of the newborn
questions.C: APGAR score combined with umbilical artery blood pH are strong predictors of neonatal death.
questions.explanation: APGAR score combined with umbilical artery blood pH are strong predictors of neonatal death. 1-minute APGAR score signals the need for resuscitation, while scores at 5, 15, and 20 minutes may indicate the probability of successful resuscitation.

questions.q: Which of the following APGAR scores indicates presence of moderate asphyxia
questions.explanation: An APGAR score of 4-6 indicates moderate asphyxia, while scores of 0-3 indicate severe asphyxia and 7 and above indicate vigorous infants without asphyxia.

questions.q: The following factors affect APGAR score
questions.explanation: Factors affecting APGAR score include immaturity, spinal cord injury, analgesics, congenital neuropathy, and myopathy.

questions.q: One of the following gestational ages indicates preterm
questions.explanation: Gestational age less than 37 weeks is considered preterm. Term births occur between 38 to 41 weeks GA, and greater than 42 weeks GA is post-term.

questions.q: The following are etiologies of preterm infants
questions.explanation: Completed antenatal care is not an etiology or risk factor for preterm infants; rather, it reduces the risk.

questions.q: Preterm infants present with the following
questions.explanation: Preterm infants often present with multisystemic clinical manifestations, including respiratory distress syndrome, vitamin K deficiency, necrotizing enterocolitis, among others.

questions.q: Nursery care in the management of prematurity includes
questions.B: Removal of parents in the care of the baby
questions.explanation: Nursery care for premature infants involves active involvement of parents in the care process, along with oxygen therapy, thermal control, feeding, and infection control.

questions.q: The following are metabolic presentations in prematurity except
questions.explanation: Metabolic presentations in prematurity include hypocalcemia, metabolic acidosis, and hypoglycemia. Hyperthermia is not typically observed in premature infants.

questions.q: Which of the following is not a factor affecting growth and development
questions.explanation: Factors affecting growth and development include hereditary factors, environmental influences, malposition in the uterus, maternal health conditions such as diabetes, among others.

questions.q: Which of the following describes the neonatal stage
questions.explanation: The neonatal stage encompasses the period from birth to the end of the first month of life. It is followed by the infancy stage, which spans from 1 month to the end of 1 year.

questions.q: Which is correct regarding growth in infancy
questions.A: Growth in infancy is dependent on growth hormone
questions.B: Growth in the infancy period is nutrition dependent
questions.C: It is the period with the lowest growth velocity
questions.explanation: Growth in the infancy period is primarily dependent on nutrition (e.g., insulin, thyroid) rather than growth hormone. Additionally, infancy is characterized by the highest growth velocity, not the lowest.

questions.q: Which is correct about childhood growth
questions.A: Childhood growth phase starts from 6 -12 months & continues till puberty
questions.explanation: Childhood growth phase starts from 6 -12 months and continues until puberty. It is under hormonal control (e.g., GH-IGF-1, thyroid hormone, insulin) and is influenced by nutrition. Infancy stage is primarily nutrition dependent.

questions.q: Age of puberty in girls
questions.explanation: Puberty typically occurs between 8 and 13 years of age in girls, and between 9 and 14 years of age in boys.

questions.q: A girl is said to be in Tanner 3 stage of breast development. What will you expect to see in this stage
questions.A: Breast bud stage. Elevation of the breast and papilla as a small mound. Enlargement of the areola diameter
questions.B: Projection of the areola and papilla to form a secondary mound above the level of the breast.
questions.C: Further enlargement and elevation of the breast and areola, with no separation of their contours.
questions.explanation: Tanner stage 3 of breast development is characterized by further enlargement and elevation of the breast and areola, with no separation of their contours.

questions.q: The following hormone is not involved in the puberty growth phase
questions.explanation: Gonadotropin Releasing Hormone, Gonadotropins (FSH & LH), Growth Hormone, Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IGF1), Gonadal Steroids, Insulin, Leptin are all involved in the pubertal growth phase.

questions.q: Sparse growth of slightly pigmented downy hair chiefly at the base of the penis is the presentation of what pubic hair Tanner stage in boys
questions.explanation: Tanner Stage 2 is characterized by sparse growth of slightly pigmented downy hair chiefly at the base of the penis.

questions.q: The following are risk factors of hyperbilirubinemia
questions.explanation: Term babies are not at an increased risk of hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.q: Most common causes of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in Nigeria include all
questions.explanation: Common causes of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in Nigeria include ABO incompatibility, G6PD Deficiency, and infection, among others.

questions.q: Causes of Jaundice in the first 24 hours include
questions.B: Congenital infection such as CMV, rubella
questions.explanation: Causes of jaundice in the first 24 hours of life include erythroblastosis fetalis, congenital infections (e.g., CMV, rubella), and hemolysis, among others.

questions.q: Which is incorrect about the clinical manifestations of jaundice
questions.A: Jaundice may be present at birth or may appear at any time during the neonatal period, depending on etiology
questions.B: Dermal pressure may reveal the anatomic progression of jaundice (face = 5 mg/dL; nipple line = 10mg/dL; mid-abdomen = 15 mg/dL; soles = 20 mg/dL)
questions.C: Whereas jaundice from deposition of indirect bilirubin in the skin tends to appear bright yellow or orange, jaundice of the obstructive type (direct bilirubin) has a greenish or muddy yellow cast.
questions.explanation: All statements are correct regarding the clinical manifestations of jaundice.

questions.q: What is the primary treatment option of jaundice
questions.explanation: Phototherapy and, if unsuccessful, exchange transfusion remain the primary treatment modalities used to keep the maximal total serum bilirubin below the pathologic levels.

questions.q: The following are complications of phototherapy
questions.explanation: Constipation is a complication of phototherapy, not loose stool. Other complications include erythematous macular rash, purpuric rash associated with transient porphyrinemia, overheating (hyperthermia), and dehydration (increased insensible water loss, diarrhea).

questions.q: The following are criteria for SIRS
questions.A: Leukocyte count elevated or depressed for age
questions.B: Core temperature (oral, rectal, bladder, or central catheter) >38.50C or <360C
questions.C: Respiratory rate >2 SD above normal for age
questions.explanation: SIRS is defined as two out of four of the following criteria, one of which MUST be abnormal temperature or an abnormal leucocyte count. Respiratory rate >2 SD above normal for age and tachycardia or bradycardia are also criteria for SIRS.

questions.q: Severe sepsis is characterized as
questions.B: Sepsis with no end organ damage
questions.C: Sepsis plus 2 or more organ dysfunction
questions.explanation: Severe sepsis is defined as sepsis plus 2 or more organ dysfunctions (respiratory, renal, neurologic, hematologic, or hepatic) OR sepsis plus either cardiovascular dysfunction or Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS).

questions.q: The following are risk factors of neonatal sepsis
questions.explanation: Risk factors of neonatal sepsis include premature rupture of membrane (PROM) occurring ≥ 18 hours before birth, maternal chorioamnionitis, colonization with GBS, preterm delivery, prolonged/difficult delivery, instrumental delivery, and low APGAR score.

questions.q: All are clinical manifestations of neonatal sepsis
questions.explanation: Less vigorous sucking/poor feeding is a feature of neonatal sepsis, not normal feeding. Other presentations include diminished spontaneous activity, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal distention, jitteriness, seizures, skin rash. Non-specific signs include lethargy, apnea, bradycardia, temperature instability, respiratory distress, and jaundice.

questions.q: The World Health Organization identified clinical signs that should prompt neonatal referral to a hospital include
questions.explanation: Clinical signs that should prompt neonatal referral to a hospital according to the World Health Organization include difficulty feeding, convulsions, movement only when stimulated, respiratory rate >60 per min, severe chest in drawing, axillary temperature >37.5 °C or <35.5 °C, cyanosis, and grunting.

questions.q: Which of the following investigation is diagnostic of neonatal sepsis
questions.explanation: Culture is the diagnostic investigation for neonatal sepsis. A finding of ≥ 5 white blood cells/high-power field in the spun urine or any organisms in a fresh unspun gram-stained sample is presumptive evidence of a urinary tract infection (UTI). Chest x-ray should be performed in neonates with respiratory symptoms.

questions.q: Which is incorrect regarding the management of neonatal sepsis
questions.A: Duration of IV therapy should be a minimum of 5-7 days
questions.B: When meningitis is present, a total course of 11 days intravenous therapy is recommended.
questions.C: Initial therapy should include ampicillin plus an aminoglycoside
questions.D: Cefotaxime may be added to or substituted for the aminoglycoside if meningitis caused by a gram-negative organism is suspected.
questions.explanation: When meningitis is present, the course of therapy recommended increases to 21 days, not 11 days.

questions.q: Preventive measures for neonatal sepsis include:
questions.explanation: Preventive measures for neonatal sepsis include good antenatal care, GBS prophylaxis (e.g., penicillin, ampicillin, or cefazolin given

questions.q: The following are features of moderately severe perinatal asphyxia
questions.D: Seizure may occur within 24hours of life
questions.explanation: Absent neonatal reflexes are a feature of SEVERE perinatal asphyxia, not moderately severe asphyxia.

questions.q: The following are predisposing factors of perinatal asphyxia
questions.explanation: PROM, preeclampsia, prematurity, eclampsia, abruptio placenta, placenta previa, macrosomia, and post-maturity are all predisposing factors of perinatal asphyxia.

questions.q: The expected height of a 1-year-old term baby is
questions.explanation: The expected height of a 1-year-old term baby is 75cm.

questions.q: What is the adequate caloric requirement of a 6-month-old
questions.explanation: The adequate caloric requirement of a 6-month-old is 110 kcal/kg/d.

questions.q: The following are benefits of breastfeeding on the child
questions.A: It is the first immunization a baby gets
questions.B: It contains the adequate nutrients in the right proportion.
questions.C: It improves bond between mother and child.
questions.explanation: Breastfeeding provides numerous benefits to the child, including being the first immunization, containing adequate nutrients, and improving the bond between mother and child.

questions.q: Which is incorrect about breastfeeding
questions.A: WHO recommends Exclusive Breast Feeding for the 1st 6months of life
questions.B: After 6 months alternative feeds can be introduced but breastfeeding continues for 1 year
questions.C: Anti-infective properties of breast milk (protects against diarrhea, respiratory/urinary infections, NEC, septicemia, meningitis)
questions.D: Contains Antibodies; Ig A,G,E,M. antiviral antibodies.
questions.explanation: WHO recommends exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months of life, followed by adequate complementary feeding while breastfeeding continues until the child is at least 2 years old.

questions.q: Benefits of breastfeeding to the mother includes
questions.C: Reduces the risk of breast cancer
questions.explanation: Benefits of breastfeeding to the mother include serving as a contraceptive, aiding in uterine involution, and reducing the risk of breast cancer.

questions.q: What year was EPI currently known as NPI introduced in Nigeria
questions.explanation: EPI (Expanded Programme on Immunization), currently known as NPI (National Programme on Immunization), was introduced in Nigeria in 1979.

questions.q: Content of the pentavalent vaccine include
questions.explanation: The pentavalent vaccine includes tetanus, hemophilus influenza type b, diphtheria, hepatitis B, and pertussis. Measles is not a component of the pentavalent vaccine but rather the MMR vaccine (measles, mumps, and rubella).

questions.q: The following vaccines are administered at birth
questions.explanation: PCV is not administered at birth. It is administered at 6, 10, and 14 weeks.

questions.q: The following are contraindications of vaccines
questions.B: History of allergic reaction to previous administration
questions.explanation: All of the options listed are contraindications for vaccines.

questions.q: Vaccine failure is due to the following
questions.explanation: Vaccine failure can occur due to factors such as lack of potency, expired vaccine, or wrong route of administration. However, a well-fed baby is not a reason for vaccine failure; rather, severe malnutrition can impact vaccine effectiveness.

questions.q: Challenges faced by immunization programs include
questions.B: Poor accountability framework and data management
questions.explanation: The challenges faced by immunization programs include lack of awareness, poor accountability framework and data management, inadequate skilled personnel and equipment, and more.

questions.q: Which of the following is used in the measurement of mid-arm circumference
questions.explanation: Mid-arm circumference is measured with Shakir's tape.

questions.q: Which is incorrect
questions.A: The infant weight doubles by 4-5 months
questions.B: The infant weight triples by 10-12 months
questions.D: Average height for infant boys is 50cm
questions.explanation: The normal head circumference for infants is typically between 33-35 cm.

questions.q: At what age does the anterior fontanelle close
questions.explanation: The anterior fontanelle closes by 12-18 months of age.

questions.q: Which is incorrect
questions.A: Anthropometry is an essential component of clinical examination of infants, children & pregnant women.
questions.B: It is used to identify specific nutritional deficiencies
questions.C: They are used to evaluate both under & overnutrition.
questions.D: The measured values reflect the current nutritional status & don’t differentiate between acute & chronic changes.
questions.explanation: Anthropometry is not used to identify specific nutritional deficiencies.

questions.q: Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by
questions.explanation: Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by heavy proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and edema, not hyperalbuminemia.

questions.q: The following drugs can cause nephrotic syndrome
questions.explanation: Captopril, gold, NSAIDs, pamidronate, and interferon are all drugs that can lead to nephrotic syndrome.

questions.q: Which of the following responds well to steroid therapy
questions.explanation: Minimal change disease responds well to steroid therapy.

questions.q: Clinical presentations of nephrotic syndrome includes
questions.explanation: Nephrotic syndrome can present with peri-orbital puffiness, ascites, and generalized edema.

questions.q: Which is correct regarding investigations in nephrotic syndrome
questions.explanation: In nephrotic syndrome, ANA (Antinuclear antibodies) may be elevated among other findings such as proteinuria, low serum albumin, and elevated serum cholesterol.

questions.q: Relapse in nephrotic syndrome is characterized by
questions.A: Creatinine ratio of <0.2 or <1+ protein on urine dipstick for 3 consecutive days
questions.C: Creatinine ratio of >2 or ≥3+ protein on urine dipstick testing for 3 consecutive days
questions.explanation: Relapse in nephrotic syndrome is defined by a urine protein: creatinine ratio of >2 or ≥3+ protein on urine dipstick testing for 3 consecutive days.

questions.q: Which of the following is resistant to steroids
questions.explanation: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is known to be resistant to steroid therapy.

questions.q: Causes of pre-renal acute kidney injury include
questions.explanation: Pre-renal acute kidney injury is often caused by factors such as dehydration, hemorrhage, or sepsis. Lupus is an intrinsic cause, not pre-renal.

questions.q: The following are clinical presentations of AKI
questions.C: Body swelling starting from the face
questions.explanation: Diminished urine volume, not increased, is a clinical presentation of AKI. Malaise, body swelling, and hypertension are also observed.

questions.q: All are complications of AKI except
questions.explanation: Drowsiness is a symptom of AKI, not a complication.

questions.q: Clinical indication for dialysis include all
questions.explanation: Serum urea >25mmol/l is a biochemical indication for dialysis, not a clinical one.

questions.q: Clinical features of AGN include
questions.explanation: Acute glomerulonephritis (AGN) is characterized by a tetrad of symptoms including hypertension, edema, hematuria, and oliguria.

questions.q: Which of the following common causes of AGN presents with abdominal pain and rash
questions.explanation: Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is associated with abdominal symptoms and a rash.

questions.q: Clinical presentations of AGN include
questions.A: Altered urine appearance e.g. smoky, coca cola colored
questions.B: Facial puffiness more in the morning and regress as the day passes
questions.explanation: Reduction in urine quantity is seen in AGN, not an increase.

questions.q: What laboratory feature is not expected in AGN
questions.explanation: In AGN, there is typically an increase, not a decrease, in anti-streptolysin O titer.

questions.q: The following are complications of AGN
questions.explanation: Complications of AGN include AKI, CKD, hypertensive encephalopathy, pulmonary edema, and congestive cardiac failure.

questions.q: Which of the following is not an indication for biopsy in AGN
questions.explanation: Proteinuria >6 months, not >3 months, is an indication for biopsy in AGN.

questions.q: The following are under 5 causes of CKD except
questions.explanation: HIV-associated nephropathy typically occurs in adults, not in children under 5.

questions.q: Complications of CKD include
questions.D: Acidosis due to loss of bicarbonate
questions.explanation: Hypercalcemia can occur as a complication of CKD.

questions.q: What type of anemia is present in CKD
questions.explanation: Normocytic normochromic anemia is commonly seen in CKD.

questions.q: Management of anemia and growth retardation in CKD
questions.C: Recombinant erythropoietin and recombinant growth hormone
questions.explanation: Recombinant human erythropoietin and growth hormone are used in the management of anemia and growth retardation in CKD.

questions.q: Which is incorrect regarding UTI
questions.A: Asymptomatic bacteriuria - is a term when bacteria are found in repeated samples from a child who does not report symptoms
questions.B: UTIs develop often in the 1st year of life.
questions.C: Commoner in males than females after 6 months of life. Recurrence rates are higher in males than females.
questions.D: Etiology Usually bacterial, but may be parasitic, viral or fungal.
questions.explanation: UTIs are more common in females after 6 months of life. Recurrence rates are higher in females than males.

questions.q: What is the most common bacteria causing UTI
questions.explanation: Escherichia coli (E. coli) is the most common bacteria causing UTIs, accounting for 80-90% of cases.

questions.q: The most common source of UTI in neonates is
questions.C: Ascending infection from the perineum and urethra
questions.explanation: Hematogenous spread is the most common source of UTI in neonates.

questions.q: Which of the following investigations is the gold standard in the diagnosis of UTI
questions.explanation: Urine culture is considered the gold standard in diagnosing UTI.

questions.q: Urinalysis in UTI reveals the following
questions.explanation: Urinalysis in UTI typically reveals leucocyte esterase, nitrite, proteinuria, and hematuria.

questions.q: Life span of red blood cells in sickle cell anemia
questions.explanation: The life span of red blood cells in sickle cell anemia is approximately 15-25 days, with an average of 17 days.

questions.q: The following are features of sickle cell habitus
questions.explanation: Sickle cell habitus includes characteristics such as being small for gestational age, frontal bossing, and hepatosplenomegaly, among others.

questions.q: What is the first presentation of SCA
questions.explanation: Dactylitis (hand and foot syndrome) is often the first presentation of sickle cell anemia.

questions.q: The following are triggers of vaso-occlusive crisis
questions.explanation: Vaso-occlusive crisis in sickle cell anemia can be triggered by stress, infection, dehydration, hypoxia, acidosis, and temperature extremes.

questions.q: The following organisms can cause chest infection in acute chest syndrome of SCA
questions.explanation: Common organisms causing chest infection in acute chest syndrome of sickle cell anemia include S. pneumoniae, M. pneumoniae, and Chlamydia sp.

questions.q: Which is incorrect
questions.A: Priapism is defined as persistent, purposeless, painful penile erection
questions.B: Mean age of the first episode is 10 years (- 90% will have experienced it by 30 years)
questions.C: Recurrent prolonged episodes are associated with penile fibrosis and impotence
questions.explanation: The mean age of the first episode of priapism is 15 years (- 90% will have experienced it by 20 years).

questions.q: What virus is associated with aplastic crisis of SCA
questions.explanation: Parvovirus B19 is associated with aplastic crisis in sickle cell anemia.

questions.q: The following are chronic complications of sickle cell anemia
questions.explanation: Chronic complications of sickle cell anemia include hepatosplenomegaly, osteomyelitis, and pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.q: Which of the following drugs is used in the prophylaxis of malaria in SCA
questions.explanation: Proguanil is used in the prophylaxis against malaria in sickle cell anemia.

questions.q: Severe anemia is
questions.explanation: Severe anemia is defined as venous Hematocrit or PCV <15%.

questions.q: Which is incorrect about severe anemia
questions.A: On examination patient may be acutely ill-looking evidenced by respiratory distress, pale, may be dehydrated, febrile, cold clammy extremities (in shock), pedal edema.
questions.explanation: Severe anemia may present with tachypnea, but typically with reduced SPO2, not increased SPO2.

questions.q: One of these is not a method of transmission of malaria
questions.explanation: Malaria can be transmitted through blood transfusion, maternal to child transmission, and bites by female Anopheles mosquitoes, but not through sexual contact.

questions.q: Uncomplicated malaria
questions.A: Malaria with presence of end-organ damage
questions.explanation: Uncomplicated malaria refers to malaria without end-organ damage.

questions.q: An endemic area with >75% transmission throughout the year is referred to
questions.explanation: A holoendemic area has >75% transmission of infection throughout the year.

questions.q: The following are features of complicated malaria
questions.explanation: Loss of appetite is a feature of uncomplicated malaria, not complicated malaria, which presents with features of end-organ damage.

questions.q: Malaria risk factors include
questions.explanation: Hypertension is not a risk factor for malaria.

questions.q: The following are laboratory features of severe malaria
questions.explanation: Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema is a feature of severe malaria, not cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

questions.q: All are complications of severe malaria
questions.explanation: Hypothyroidism is not a complication of severe malaria.

questions.q: Malaria prophylaxis in sickle cell disease patients is achieved by administration of which drug
questions.explanation: Proguanil is the drug of choice for malaria prophylaxis in sickle cell disease patients.

questions.q: Measures for the prevention of malaria
questions.B: Getting rid of bushes and stagnant waters
questions.D: Sleeping without a mosquito net in an endemic area
questions.explanation: Using mosquito nets is one of the measures for preventing malaria infection, especially in endemic areas.

questions.q: Incubation period of tetanus
questions.explanation: The incubation period of tetanus is 3-21 days.

questions.q: What is the first sign of tetanus infection
questions.explanation: The first unmistakable sign of tetanus is trismus, also known as locked jaw.

questions.q: Convenient settings that expose to tetanus infections involve
questions.explanation: Deep wounds, high atmospheric temperature, high humidity, and composition of soil are all convenient settings for tetanus infection.

questions.q: The following are late complications of tetanus
questions.D: Fractures of long bones and spine
questions.explanation: Laryngospasm is an early complication of tetanus, not a late one.

questions.q: Opisthotonos
questions.A: Hypertonia of trunk muscles, anterior abdominal wall muscle rigidity
questions.explanation: Opisthotonus is characterized by hypertonia of trunk muscles and anterior abdominal wall muscle rigidity.

questions.q: Classes of tetanus include
questions.explanation: Tetanus can clinically be classified into generalized, localized, cephalic, and neonatal disease.

questions.q: What organism is responsible for the transmission of yellow fever
questions.explanation: Aedes Aegyptus mosquito transmits yellow fever.

questions.q: Yellow fever. Which one is correct
questions.A: Incubation period in humans is 10 days
questions.explanation: Hepatic involvement in yellow fever can result in jaundice.

questions.q: When is the yellow fever vaccine administered
questions.explanation: Yellow fever vaccine is administered at 9 months of age.

questions.q: Which of the following is yellow fever virus family
questions.explanation: Yellow fever is a member of the flavivirus family.

questions.q: Which is incorrect about HIV in children
questions.A: Majority (90%) of infected children acquire the infection through MTCT. This occurs during pregnancy, delivery and breastfeeding.
questions.B: In absence of any intervention, the risk of MTCT is 25 - 40% in non-breastfeeding populations
questions.C: In utero: 5-10%, during labor: 15% during breastfeeding: 5-15%
questions.explanation: All statements are correct regarding HIV in children.

questions.q: Clinical presentation of HIV in children includes
questions.explanation: All listed clinical presentations are associated with HIV in children.

questions.q: What is the confirmatory test for HIV
questions.explanation: The Western blot test is the confirmatory test for HIV.

questions.q: The following are indications for ART except
questions.C: Age< 12 months irrespective of the clinical or immunologic state
questions.explanation: Age >12 months is not an indication for ART.

questions.q: HIV progress to AIDS within
questions.explanation: In the absence of treatment, HIV typically progresses to AIDS within 7-10 years.

questions.q: Which is incorrect regarding neuroblastoma
questions.B: Epidemiology: 1st 4 years of life. Mean age of 2yrs
questions.explanation: Neuroblastoma typically presents with hypertension due to catecholamine secretion, not hypotension.

questions.q: Clinical presentations of neuroblastoma include
questions.B: Orbital features (Ecchymosis, Proptosis) due to metastasis to periorbital region
questions.explanation: All listed clinical presentations are associated with neuroblastoma.

questions.q: Common site of metastases of neuroblastoma except
questions.explanation: Brain is not a common site of metastases of neuroblastoma.

questions.q: Which of the following is a worst prognostic factor for neuroblastoma
questions.explanation: Abdominal involvement is a worse prognostic factor for neuroblastoma.

questions.q: Wilm’s tumor, which is incorrect
questions.A: Most common urinary tract malignancy in children
questions.D: Accounts for 6% of all pediatric tumors in developed countries
questions.explanation: Wilm’s tumor can be bilateral in 5-10% of cases.

questions.q: Which of the following gene is involved in Wilm’s tumor pathogenesis
questions.explanation: WT1 gene is involved in Wilm’s tumor pathogenesis.

questions.q: A 5-year-old boy with hematuria, abdominal pain and flank mass complains of severe pruritus, lab values reveal elevated PCV. What is the likely cause of this presentation
questions.C: Polycythemia vera secondary to Wilm’s tumor
questions.explanation: The likely cause of this presentation is polycythemia vera secondary to Wilm’s tumor.

questions.q: One of the following is a worst prognostic factor of Wilm’s tumor
questions.explanation: Bilateral involvement has a worse prognosis in Wilm’s tumor.

questions.q: Which is correct about retinoblastoma
questions.B: It is the most common intraocular malignancy and constitutes 4% of childhood malignancy
questions.explanation: Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular malignancy and constitutes 4% of childhood malignancy.

questions.q: The following are clinical presentations of retinoblastoma
questions.explanation: All listed clinical presentations are associated with retinoblastoma.

questions.q: Complications of retinoblastoma
questions.explanation: All listed complications can occur in retinoblastoma.

questions.q: All are risk factors of rhabdomyosarcoma
questions.explanation: Rhabdomyosarcoma is more common in males than females.

questions.q: What is the most common affected site in rhabdomyosarcoma
questions.explanation: Head & Neck is the most affected site in rhabdomyosarcoma.

questions.q: Chromosomal translocation associated with Burkitt lymphoma is
questions.explanation: Translocation 8:14 is associated with Burkitt lymphoma.

questions.q: The following are risk factors of Burkitt lymphoma
questions.explanation: All listed factors are risk factors for Burkitt lymphoma.

questions.q: Which of the following is not a feature of endemic variant Burkitt lymphoma
questions.C: Painless and fast tooth or loose tooth at early stage
questions.explanation: The sporadic variant, not the endemic variant, of Burkitt lymphoma is common in older children.

questions.q: Which of the following is the most important investigation in the diagnosis of retinoblastoma
questions.explanation: under anesthesia (fundoscopy) is the single most important test.

questions.130: The following are precautions before the commencement of chemotherapy
questions.B: Total white blood count >=3000 cells/ mm3
questions.explanation: Precautions before commencement of chemotherapy include PVC>=30%, Total white blood count >=3000 cells/ mm3, Absolute neutrophil count>= 1000 cells /mm3, Platelet >= 100,000 cells /mm3.
